text: XVI Every body in and about Highbury who had ever visited Mr. Elton , was disposed to pay him attention on his marriage .
text_tokenized: XVI Every body in and about Highbury who had ever visited Mr. Elton , was disposed to pay him attention on his marriage .

text: Dinner - parties and evening - parties were made for him and his lady ; and invitations flowed in so fast that she had soon the pleasure of apprehending they were never to have a disengaged day .
text_tokenized: Dinner - parties and evening - parties were made for him and his lady ; and invitations flowed in so fast that she had soon the pleasure of apprehending they were never to have a disengaged day .

text: " I see what a life I am to lead among you .
text_tokenized: " I see what a life I am to lead among you .

text: Upon my word we shall be absolutely dissipated .

text: If this is living in the country , it is nothing very formidable .

text: From Monday next to Saturday , I assure you we have not a disengaged day!--A woman with fewer resources than I have , need not have been at a loss . "
text_tokenized: From Monday next to Saturday , I assure you we have not a disengaged day!--A woman with fewer resources than I have , need not have been at a loss . "

text: Her Bath habits made evening - parties perfectly natural to her , and Maple Grove had given her a taste for dinners .

text: She was a little shocked at the want of two drawing rooms , at the poor attempt at rout - cakes , and there being no ice in the Highbury card - parties .

text: Mrs. Bates , Mrs. Perry , Mrs. Goddard and others , were a good deal behind - hand in knowledge of the world , but she would soon shew them how every thing ought to be arranged . In the course of the spring she must return their civilities by one very superior party -- in which her card - tables should be set out with their separate candles and unbroken packs in the true style -- and more waiters engaged for the evening than their own establishment could furnish , to carry round the refreshments at exactly the proper hour , and in the proper order .

text: The two eldest little Knightleys were engaged to pay their grandpapa and aunt a visit of some weeks in the spring , and their papa now proposed bringing them , and staying one whole day at Hartfield -- which one day would be the very day of this party.--His professional engagements did not allow of his being put off , but both father and daughter were disturbed by its happening so .

text: Mr. Woodhouse considered eight persons at dinner together as the utmost that his nerves could bear-- and here would be a ninth -- and Emma apprehended that it would be a ninth very much out of humour at not being able to come even to Hartfield for forty - eight hours without falling in with a dinner - party .

text: Mrs. Elton , as elegant as lace and pearls could make her , he looked at in silence-- wanting only to observe enough for Isabella 's information -- but Miss Fairfax was an old acquaintance and a quiet girl , and he could talk to her . He had met her before breakfast as he was returning from a walk with his little boys , when it had been just beginning to rain .

text: " " I went only to the post - office , " said she , " and reached home before the rain was much .

text: When you have lived to my age , you will begin to think letters are never worth going through the rain for . " There was a little blush , and then this answer , " I must not hope to be ever situated as you are , in the midst of every dearest connexion , and therefore I can not expect that simply growing older should make me indifferent about letters . " " Indifferent !

text: Letters are no matter of indifference ; they are generally a very positive curse . " " You are speaking of letters of business ; mine are letters of friendship . " " I have often thought them the worst of the two , " replied he coolly .

text: " Business , you know , may bring money , but friendship hardly ever does .

text: I know Mr. John Knightley too well-- I am very sure he understands the value of friendship as well as any body .

text: I can easily believe that letters are very little to you , much less than to me , but it is not your being ten years older than myself which makes the difference , it is not age , but situation . You have every body dearest to you always at hand , I , probably , never shall again ; and therefore till I have outlived all my affections , a post - office , I think , must always have power to draw me out , in worse weather than to - day . " " When I talked of your being altered by time , by the progress of years , " said John Knightley , " I meant to imply the change of situation which time usually brings . I consider one as including the other .

text: A pleasant " thank you " seemed meant to laugh it off , but a blush , a quivering lip , a tear in the eye , shewed that it was felt beyond a laugh . Her attention was now claimed by Mr. Woodhouse , who being , according to his custom on such occasions , making the circle of his guests , and paying his particular compliments to the ladies , was ending with her -- and with all his mildest urbanity , said , " I am very sorry to hear , Miss Fairfax , of your being out this morning in the rain . Young ladies should take care of themselves.--

text: " I never saw any gentleman 's handwriting"--Emma began , looking also at Mrs. Weston ; but stopped , on perceiving that Mrs. Weston was attending to some one else -- and the pause gave her time to reflect , " Now , how am I going to introduce him?--Am I unequal to speaking his name at once before all these people ?

text: Is it necessary for me to use any roundabout phrase?--Your Yorkshire friend-- your correspondent in Yorkshire;--that would be the way , I suppose , if I were very bad.--No , I can pronounce his name without the smallest distress . I certainly get better and better.--Now for it .
text_tokenized: Is it necessary for me to use any roundabout phrase?--Your Yorkshire friend-- your correspondent in Yorkshire;--that would be the way , I suppose , if I were very bad.--No , I can pronounce his name without the smallest distress . I certainly get better and better.--Now for it .

text: " Mrs. Weston was disengaged and Emma began again--"Mr . Frank Churchill writes one of the best gentleman 's hands I ever saw .
text_tokenized: " Mrs. Weston was disengaged and Emma began again--"Mr . Frank Churchill writes one of the best gentleman 's hands I ever saw .

text: " I do not admire it , " said Mr. Knightley .
text_tokenized: " I do not admire it , " said Mr. Knightley .

text: " It is too small-- wants strength .
text_tokenized: " It is too small-- wants strength .

text: It is like a woman 's writing . " This was not submitted to by either lady .
text_tokenized: It is like a woman 's writing . " This was not submitted to by either lady .

text: They vindicated him against the base aspersion .
text_tokenized: They vindicated him against the base aspersion .

text: " No , it by no means wanted strength-- it was not a large hand , but very clear and certainly strong .
text_tokenized: " No , it by no means wanted strength-- it was not a large hand , but very clear and certainly strong .

text: Had not Mrs. Weston any letter about her to produce ? "
text_tokenized: Had not Mrs. Weston any letter about her to produce ? "

text: No , she had heard from him very lately , but having answered the letter , had put it away .
text_tokenized: No , she had heard from him very lately , but having answered the letter , had put it away .

text: " If we were in the other room , " said Emma , " if I had my writing - desk , I am sure I could produce a specimen .
text_tokenized: " If we were in the other room , " said Emma , " if I had my writing - desk , I am sure I could produce a specimen .

text: I have a note of his.-- Do not you remember , Mrs. Weston , employing him to write for you one day ? " " He chose to say he was employed"-- " Well , well , I have that note ; and can shew it after dinner to convince Mr. Knightley . "
text_tokenized: I have a note of his.-- Do not you remember , Mrs. Weston , employing him to write for you one day ? " " He chose to say he was employed"-- " Well , well , I have that note ; and can shew it after dinner to convince Mr. Knightley . "

text: " Oh !
text_tokenized: " Oh !

text: when a gallant young man , like Mr. Frank Churchill , " said Mr. Knightley dryly , " writes to a fair lady like Miss Woodhouse , he will , of course , put forth his best .
text_tokenized: when a gallant young man , like Mr. Frank Churchill , " said Mr. Knightley dryly , " writes to a fair lady like Miss Woodhouse , he will , of course , put forth his best .

text_tokenized: Dinner was on table.--Mrs

text: . Elton , before she could be spoken to , was ready ; and before Mr. Woodhouse had reached her with his request to be allowed to hand her into the dining - parlour , was saying-- " Must I go first ?
text_tokenized: . Elton , before she could be spoken to , was ready ; and before Mr. Woodhouse had reached her with his request to be allowed to hand her into the dining - parlour , was saying-- " Must I go first ?

text: I really am ashamed of always leading the way . "
text_tokenized: I really am ashamed of always leading the way . "

text: Jane 's solicitude about fetching her own letters had not escaped Emma .
text_tokenized: Jane 's solicitude about fetching her own letters had not escaped Emma .

text: She had heard and seen it all ; and felt some curiosity to know whether the wet walk of this morning had produced any .
text_tokenized: She had heard and seen it all ; and felt some curiosity to know whether the wet walk of this morning had produced any .

text: She suspected that it _ had _ ; that it would not have been so resolutely encountered but in full expectation of hearing from some one very dear , and that it had not been in vain . She thought there was an air of greater happiness than usual -- a glow both of complexion and spirits .
text_tokenized: She suspected that it _ had _ ; that it would not have been so resolutely encountered but in full expectation of hearing from some one very dear , and that it had not been in vain . She thought there was an air of greater happiness than usual -- a glow both of complexion and spirits .

text: She could have made an inquiry or two , as to the expedition and the expense of the Irish mails;--it was at her tongue 's end-- but she abstained .
text_tokenized: She could have made an inquiry or two , as to the expedition and the expense of the Irish mails;--it was at her tongue 's end-- but she abstained .

text: She was quite determined not to utter a word that should hurt Jane Fairfax 's feelings ; and they followed the other ladies out of the room , arm in arm , with an appearance of good - will highly becoming to the beauty and grace of each .
